reps.thinking: The notebook provides the Dandiset ID, title, a brief overview of the contents (acetylcholine dynamics, brain states, imaging data, behavioral monitoring), and some key metadata fields like session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. It also shows example data from the Dandiset, including behavioral data (eye tracking and pupil size), calcium fluorescence traces, summary images, and segmentation masks. Therefore, the notebook fulfills most of the criteria for level 9. Providing a detailed description including purpose, contents, and key metadata fields.

The notebook provides the Dandiset's title, a description, the keywords and citation. It also provides a link to the dandiset via the DANDI API, allowing data access. Moreover, the notebook's code explores the dandiset's contents by loading data and showing metadata. It also provides images and information about the dandiset's purpose and content. A thorough description including Dandiset ID, title purpose, contents and data organization .

The notebook provides the dandiset name, a concise description of what the dandiset contains, keywords, citation information, identifier, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. It also gives a brief overview of the data. All this would be basic metadata.
The notebook provides the title, ID, and purpose, and briefly overviews the basic contents (eye tracking, calcium fluorescence, summary images, segmentation masks).
However, the notebook only explores one session, and warns users to be cautions when scaling to the full dandiset. It only describes the contents, structure and key metadata for one sample file.

The notebook successfully loads the Dandiset, accesses its assets, and displays several key metadata fields such as session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. The notebook shows example loading of a single NWB file using the lindi library. Therefore, the notebook successfully loads and explores multiple metadata fields. There is no complete demonstration of working with *all* key metadata fields, which would entail showing how ALL possible fields could be accessed, or a more complete investigation and explanation of all of the loaded fields.

Taking into account these considerations, a score of 7 is appropriate. The notebook provides a good demonstration but does not achieve a 'complete' demonstration as stated in the rubric for the highest score.

The notebook successfully accesses the DANDI API, retrieves the Dandiset "001176," and accesses its assets. It then loads an NWB file associated with the Dandiset and extracts various metadata fields like session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions, effectively displaying and exploring these fields. The code executes without errors and demonstrates a thorough exploration of metadata fields, along with explanations of what is being displayed. Therefore, the notebook successfully loads and explores multiple metadata fields. Includes a Dandiset description in markdown.

The notebook uses the dandiapi library to connect to the DANDI archive and retrieve the dandiset with the ID "001176". It loads the dandiset's metadata (session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex) and displays them. It fetches assets associated with the dandiset and visualizes behavioral and imaging data from a sample NWB file. Therefore, it successfully loads and explores multiple metadata fields.

The notebook uses the DandiAPIClient to access the Dandiset and list its available assets. It proceeds to load a specific NWB file, accessing its metadata, and then visualizes data from the loaded NWB file like pupil size, eye tracking, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images, and segmentation masks. This shows a good level of asset loading, metadata access, usage examples and asset type exploration. It could be more comprehensive if it explored more deeply the connections between different asset types and/or explored all assets in the dataset, but is still doing a good job overall.

The notebook successfully loads the Dandiset assets using the DANDI API, lists available assets, loads a specific NWB file, accesses its metadata (session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, imaging plane descriptions), and visualizes behavioral and imaging data contained within the loaded asset. This suggests a reasonable grasp of loading, accessing, and using assets. Therefore, it earns a score of 8.

The notebook demonstrates loading assets using the DANDI API, lists available assets, loads a specific asset (NWB file), and accesses its metadata (session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject information, imaging plane descriptions). It also provides usage examples by visualizing behavioral data, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images, and segmentation masks from the loaded asset. Therefore, the notebook sufficiently demonstrates asset loading, metadata access, and usage examples. The notebook does not do much beyond the single NWB file, so I will not provide a score of 10.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from the DANDI archive and accesses basic information such as session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. The notebook then goes on to display behavioral data, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and segmentation masks, demonstrating access to multiple key data components within the NWB file. Therefore, the notebook demonstrates successfully opening an NWB file, showing its basic structure including components like behavioral data and imaging results, and the notebook demonstrates the basics of how to access key components. The presented visualizations provide confidence that this access is correct.

The notebook demonstrates loading an NWB file from the Dandiset using a URL, then explores the file by printing session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. Thus, the notebook shows accessing NWB components.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from the DANDI Archive, prints basic metadata such as session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, and sex, and lists the imaging plane descriptions. It also displays behavioral data (eye tracking and pupil size), calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and a segmentation mask example, all of which are components within the NWB file. However, it could provide more detailed navigation and access to various NWB data structures for a higher rating.
The notebook demonstrates loading and opening an NWB file. It also successfully demonstrates accessing several basic NWB components.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from a URL using `lindi` and `pynwb`. It then demonstrates accessing metadata like session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. The notebook also visualizes behavioral data (pupil size and eye tracking) and calcium fluorescence traces, and displays summary images and segmentation masks, all derived from data within the NWB file. This shows loading and handling a variety of data types present in the NWB file. However, the notebook does not show advanced data access techniques such as queries or filtering. Therefore it earns a score of 8.

The notebook successfully loads the NWB file from a URL using the `lindi` and `pynwb` libraries. It then accesses and prints metadata such as session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject ID, species, sex, and imaging plane descriptions. The notebook also visualizes behavioral data (pupil and eye tracking), calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and a segmentation mask. This demonstrates loading and basic handling of different data types available in the NWB file. It doesn't delve into advanced techniques, but adequately demonstrates data access and handling.

The notebook loads an NWB file from a URL and accesses basic metadata (session description, identifier, start time, experimenter, subject info). It also displays behavioral data (eye tracking, pupil size) and calcium fluorescence traces, summary images, and segmentation masks derived from the NWB file. This demonstrates successful loading of specific data types and displays them, warranting a score of 5.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from a DANDI archive and visualizes several data types, including eye tracking data, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images, and segmentation masks. The visualizations are simple, but they effectively demonstrate how to access and display different types of data stored in the NWB file. The plots have adequate descriptions,axes are appropriately labeled, and the notebook provides some context/interpretation for each. It could be improved by showing how to customize the plots further and demonstrating more advanced visualization techniques, as well as visualizing more data types within the NWB file.

The notebook successfully loads data from an NWB file and presents different types of visualizations including eye tracking/pupil size plots, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and a segmentation mask example. Each visualization is accompanied by a brief descriptive text. The visualizations are basic but clearly labeled and informative, adequately showcasing a variety of data types available in the NWB file. Therefore, it gets a score of 7.

The notebook provides code to access a specific NWB file from the Dandiset and visualizes several data types contained within the file, including eye tracking/pupil data, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and segmentation masks. The visualizations are simple plots but are well labeled and accompanied by descriptions of the data. The "tmp_scripts" calls are concerning and suggest potential issues with code execution. There's no way to know without seeing the script content. However, the images are displayed correctly, therefore allowing me to assume that the calls are valid. I'll assume the plots are generated correctly. Regardless, basic visualization is achieved. Overall, the notebook demonstrates multiple visualization types with good clarity and labeling. Therefore, I will select 7.

The notebook contains several plots illustrating behavioral data (eye tracking, pupil size), calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and segmentation masks. The plots are generally readable and have basic labels such as axis titles. However, they lack detailed information like units (though some axes mention "a.u." or "px units"), legends, or more descriptive titles. The formatting is adequate but not particularly polished. Therefore it deserves a 6.

The notebook provides several plots illustrating different aspects of the dataset, including eye tracking and pupil size, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and segmentation masks. The plots are readable and have basic labels, providing enough information to understand the data being presented. Therefore, It merits a score of 5.

The notebook contains several plots illustrating behavioral data (eye tracking and pupil size), calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and segmentation masks. The plots are generally readable, with basic labels. The axes labels are present and understandable. The formatting is adequate, but not exceptionally detailed. The quality is above just basic and simple but does not rise to a level of comprehensive formatting.

The notebook includes four plots: pupil and eye tracking, calcium fluorescence trace, summary images, and segmentation mask example. Each one shows a distinct aspect of the data (behavior, neural activity, imaging data, and segmentation). Different visualization types are also included.

The notebook includes four plots depicting eye tracking/pupil size, calcium fluorescence trace, summary images, and segmentation mask. These plots demonstrate different aspects of the dataset: behavior (eye tracking), neural activity (calcium trace), overall structure from imaging data (summary images), and image analysis results (segmentation). Since each plot presents qualitatively different information, they are considered effective, pushing the classification to 6.

The notebook incorporates four distinct plots, each shedding light on different facets of the dataset: pupil and eye-tracking data, calcium fluorescence traces, summary images from two-photon imaging, and a segmentation mask example. Each plot is effective in visualizing and conveying distinct data attributes within the study. These range from the pupil radius changes over time to specific fluorescence activations of individual cells.
